sub_topic: The investigation of the properties of the W and Z bosons in different production modes
message_1: What is the difference in the production cross-sections of the W and Z bosons in proton-proton collisions at a center-of-mass energy of 13 TeV, and how do these differences vary with respect to the transverse momentum of the bosons?
message_2:
The production cross-sections of W and Z bosons in proton-proton collisions depend on the center-of-mass energy and the parton distribution functions (PDFs) of the colliding protons. At a center-of-mass energy of 13 TeV, the production cross-sections for W and Z bosons can be calculated using the Standard Model of particle physics and experimental data from the Large Hadron Collider (LHC).

The production cross-sections for W and Z bosons are typically given in picobarns (pb). At a center-of-mass energy of 13 TeV, the total production cross-section for W bosons is approximately 30,000 pb, while for Z bosons, it is around 10,000 pb. The difference in the production cross-sections is due to the different coupling strengths of the weak force to the W and Z bosons and the different quark-antiquark combinations that can produce them.

The production cross-sections for W and Z bosons also depend on their transverse momentum (pT). As the pT of the bosons increases, the production cross-sections decrease. This is because high-pT bosons are produced in more energetic and rare parton collisions. The production cross-sections can be parametrized as a function of pT using a power-law function or an exponential function.

To study the variation of the production cross-sections with respect to the transverse momentum of the bosons, one can use Monte Carlo simulations or experimental data from the LHC. The ratio of the production cross-sections (W/Z) as a function of pT can provide insights into the underlying parton dynamics and the properties of the weak force.

In summary, the production cross-sections of W and Z bosons in proton-proton collisions at a center-of-mass energy of 13 TeV are different due to the different coupling strengths of the weak force and the different quark-antiquark combinations that produce them. The production cross-sections decrease with increasing transverse momentum of the bosons, and the ratio of the production cross-sections (W/Z) as a function of pT can provide insights into the underlying parton dynamics and the properties of the weak force.
